sections.title: International Roots of Brazil’s Internet
sections.text: The origins of the Internet in Brazil cannot be understood without looking at its international background. In the United States, the ARPANET had already proven the use of packet switching as a reliable way of connecting computers across distances. These early experiments became the reference model for many nations, including Brazil, that aimed to build their own academic networks.

sections.title: Universities Connecting Abroad
sections.text: In the 1980s, universities and research centers started to experiment with data communication. Among the pioneers were the USP, Unicamp, LNCC, and the UFRJ. These institutions connected to international networks such as BITNET, allowing the exchange of academic messages and collaboration with foreign researchers.

sections.title: From RNP to a National Internet Backbone
sections.text: A key milestone came in 1987, when the DARPA and the NSF authorized the UFRJ to officially connect to the Internet in the United States. Soon after, in 1989, the Brazilian government launched the RNP, the first nationwide academic backbone, which interconnected universities and research institutions. This initiative created a collaborative scientific environment and laid the foundation for the future TCP/IP expansion across the country.

sections.title: The Arrival of Commercial Internet
sections.text: In 1995, the Brazilian government authorized private companies to provide internet access, ending its exclusively academic character. Embratel, then a state-owned company, was among the first to offer dial-up services. Soon after, providers such as Mandic, Universo Online (UOL), and Brasil Online (BOL) became familiar names to the first Brazilian internet users.

sections.title: Broadband and Digital Inclusion (2000s)
sections.text: The spread of broadband connections gradually replaced dial-up, allowing faster and more stable access. This period also saw the growth of government initiatives for digital inclusion, such as telecenters and computer labs in public schools, which helped reduce the digital divide. The arrival of personal computers in more households expanded access to online services.

sections.title: Web 2.0 and Social Networks
sections.text: The rise of Web 2.0 gave users a central role in creating and sharing content. In Brazil, Orkut became a cultural phenomenon, dominating social interactions online. Alongside Orkut, platforms like blogs, instant messaging services such as MSN Messenger, and the first e-commerce websites marked the beginning of digital life for millions of Brazilians.

sections.title: Mobile Internet and Connectivity Expansion
sections.text: Over the past two decades, the internet has been driven by the growth of mobile access. Cell phones became the main gateway for millions of Brazilians, especially in regions where fixed broadband was limited. The rollout of 3G, 4G, and more recently 5G networks increased both reach and speed, making mobile the dominant form of internet access in the country.

sections.title: Governance and Regulation
sections.text: The creation of the Brazilian Internet Steering Committee (CGI.br) and NIC.br established a governance model involving government, academia, private sector, and civil society. Another key milestone was the Marco Civil da Internet, enacted in 2014, which guaranteed net neutrality, privacy, and freedom of expression, becoming known as Brazil’s “Internet Bill of Rights.”

sections.title: Challenges and Future Perspectives
sections.text: The internet today supports essential areas such as education, telemedicine, banking, commerce, and remote work. However, challenges remain: misinformation, cybersecurity risks, unequal access, and the regulation of big tech platforms. Looking forward, Brazil’s main goals are to expand connectivity, reduce regional inequalities, and guarantee that all citizens have access to a secure and democratic digital environment.
